title.narrative: Para ba Second Rural Poverty Reduction

description.narrative: The COOPERAR II project would support the efforts of the Government of Paraiba to reduce the incidence of rural poverty by: (a) improving access to small-scale socioeconomic infrastructure and services; (b) raising incomes and capital assets through investments in productive activities and facilitating linkages between small producers and national and international markets; and (c) strengthening the capacity of Municipal Councils (MC) and Community Associations (CA) to raise funding and harmonize policies and institutional arrangements for delivery of public investments intended to benefit the rural poor. COOPERAR II is a Repeater ooperation, using the highly participatory, community-driven development approach which was piloted and proven successful under the recently-completed COOPERAR I project.

condition.narrative: Registration of Loan with Central Bank
The Borrower shall carry out the Project according to the Operational Manual, including the Environmental Management Plan, theIndigenous Peoples# Participation Plan, and the Action Plan.
The Borrower shall, at least once a year during Project implementation on or about December 1, prepare and furnish to the Bank aplan (the Annual Operating Plan).

baseline.value: Baseline data on on producers will be collected prior to each round of proposals for productive subproject investments (year 1 and2 of the project). This will form the foundation for treatment and control groups in the context of evaluating impact.

comment.narrative: Of 102 subprojects financed to date, some 25% are productive in nature.

actual.value: Data are now being assessed on productive subprojects that have completed the first year of implemention. Results will beincludedin the Borrower Completion Report, as confirmed during the August 2013 supervision mission.

comment.narrative: For productive subprojects, asset accumulation will be assessed one year following subproject implementation. COOPERAR is usinganevaluation instrument based on Investment, Technology, Organization and Management indicators (I.T.O.G. in Portuguese) that willserve as a source for both baseline and follow-up data for assessing asset accumulation.
Per ICR from previous project, women represented 37% of beneficiaries from productive subprojects.

title.narrative: Number of people in rural areas provided with access to Improved Water Sources under the project

comment.narrative: Per ICR of previous project, 247,000 people benefited from improved water sources.
It is expected that some 7,250 families would benefit from access to improved water sources by end of project.

80% of the 444 subprojects approved to date are infrastructure, the vast majority of which are for improved water sources. Another20% of subprojects are creating income opportunities for rural community associations.

title.narrative: Families benefitted with at least one subproject

baseline.value: At ICR for the previous operation, 154,000 rural families had received benefits through subproject implemented via theirrespectivecommunity associations.

comment.narrative: This repeater operation would continue to track subprojects by community associations via the MIS, thereby making it possible topinpoint families that have obtained multiple benefits.

title.narrative: Percentage of productive subprojects with commercial arrangements

target.value: No target set, for monitoring purposes only

actual.value: 100%, including institutional markets (e.g., PNAE, PAA), supermarkets, and farmers' markets.

comment.narrative: A confirmed commercial arrangement is a prerequisite for productive subproject financing.
Reduced from 800 to 500 during the March 2012 supervision.
Benefiting some 24,800 families with water supply, cisterns and income-generating opportunities.

baseline.value: At ICR for the previous operation, productive subprojects accounted for 4% of total subprojects financed.

comment.narrative: Small ruminants, agriculture and fish farming comprise 80% of these productive subprojects.

title.narrative: Percentage of productive subprojects generating employment

baseline.value: At ICR for the previous operation, some 2/3 of productive subprojects showed a strategic orientation to markets, includingnationaland international (e.g., honey production, integrated dairy plants, fine craft items, tractors/equipment, grainsprocessing, fish farming and flower farming). Women were 37% of the beneficiaries of productive subprojects.

actual.value: The data currently being assessed on th productive subprojects will indicate job creation.

title.narrative: Precentage of associations with Quilombola, indigenous people, or women in leadership positions

baseline.value: At ICR for the previous operation, the Project demonstrated the capacity of the Northeast CDD model to both include and empowerwomen, contrary to the view that women participate but have no power. At Closing, of 222 Councils, 34 (15%) had female Presidentsand 67 (30%) had female Secretaries. Of 3,360 associations, 625 (19%) had female Presidents and 2,352 (70%) had other femaleofficeholders.

target.value: No target set, for monitoring purposes only

actual.value: 133 community associations with female presidents (33% of subprojects). Nine subprojects in Quilombola communtiies and threesubprojects in Indigenous communities.

title.narrative: Ratio of resources leveraged from other programs

baseline.value: At ICR of previous project, community associations and Municipal Councils decided the allocation of 88% of project funds andleveraged complementary, parallel funds in a 5:1 ratio.

comment.narrative: R$14.5 million have thus far been leveraged from the State's Poverty Reduction Fund (FUNCEP) and BNDES for application in projectsubprojects in the context of Local Productive Arrangements (APLs in Portuguese).
